title: # Q3 Team Udpate!!?? our team has been workng on the city bike-share app for...

parts:
# Q3 Team Udpate!!??

our team has been workng on the city bike-share app for around 3 month now and alot has happend, The main objective was simple: improve reliablity + reduce rider complainst , however each sprint reveal'd new issue's we didnt expect. some routes showed wrong ETA times by 7-12 min and customer support got, flooded; with tickets that looked similiar but weren't exactly the same.

The product meeting notes where kinda all-over the place. One manager wrote "lets just patch it quick" while another said we need a proper root-cause analyis... neither side was fully wrong, but the team kept swiching priorities every few days. ##this made engineering velocity drop hard## and morale went down too because done tasks got reopened for "minor" adjustments!!!

In week 9 we shipped a partial fix for location sync, it improved tracking by maybe 30 percent?? but then battery drain reports went up (especialy on older androids) and we had to rollback half the changes. weirdly, QA's regression sheet had a note saying "acceptable degredation" @@@ which no one rechecked before release. thats on process, not any one person.

Right now the plan is to stabilize core flows first: trip start, live map, and payment confirmation. after that, we can revisit extras like badges, social ride cards, and seasonal themes *if* capacity remains. we also need cleaner docs becuase new hires keep asking the same setup question's, and onboarding takes too long $$$ for no good reason.

final thought - the project is still viable, but only if we stop reactng to every loud request and use one shared prioritization rubric. otherwise we'll keep burning time, missing targets, and arguing in circles ^^^.

# Q3 Team Update

Our team has been working on the city bike-share app for around three months now, and a lot has happened. The main objective was simple: improve reliability and reduce rider complaints. However, each sprint revealed new issues we didn't expect. Some routes showed wrong ETA times by 7–12 minutes, and customer support was flooded with tickets that looked similar but weren't exactly the same.

The product meeting notes were all over the place. One manager said, “Let's just patch it quickly,” while another insisted on a proper root cause analysis. Neither side was fully wrong, but the team kept switching priorities every few days. **This caused engineering velocity to drop significantly**, and morale declined because completed tasks kept getting reopened for “minor” adjustments.

In week 9, we shipped a partial fix for location sync, which improved tracking by perhaps 30 percent. However, then battery drain reports increased—especially on older Android devices—and we had to roll back half of the changes. Strangely, QA’s regression sheet noted “acceptable degradation,” which no one rechecked before release. That’s a process issue, not due to any individual.

Right now, the plan is to stabilize core flows first: trip start, live map, and payment confirmation. After that, we can revisit features like badges, social ride cards, and seasonal themes, *if* capacity remains. We also need cleaner documentation because new hires keep asking the same setup questions, and onboarding takes too long—costing us time and resources for no good reason.

Final thought: the project is still viable, but only if we stop reacting to every loud request and adopt a shared prioritization rubric. Otherwise, we will keep wasting time, missing targets, and arguing in circles.
